request.description:
# Get Open Tickets

This endpoint retrieves all tickets with an "Open" status from the ticketing system. The response includes pagination support to handle large datasets efficiently.

## Query Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Required | Default | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `page` | integer | No | 1 | The page number to retrieve. Used for navigating through paginated results. |
| `per_page` | integer | No | 50 | The number of tickets to return per page. Controls the size of the result set. |

## Response Structure

The endpoint returns a JSON object with the following structure:

### `data` (array)

An array of ticket objects. Each ticket contains:

- `id` (integer): Unique identifier for the ticket
    
- `subject` (string): The ticket's subject line
    
- `content` (string): The full content/description of the ticket
    
- `status` (string): Current status of the ticket (will be "Open" for this endpoint)
    
- `status_id` (integer): Numeric identifier for the status (1 = Open)
    
- `created_at` (string): ISO 8601 timestamp when the ticket was created
    
- `updated_at` (string): ISO 8601 timestamp when the ticket was last updated
    
- `user` (object): Information about the user who created the ticket
    - `id` (integer): User's unique identifier
        
    - `name` (string): User's full name
        
    - `email` (string): User's email address
        

### `links` (object)

Pagination navigation links:

- `first`: URL to the first page
    
- `last`: URL to the last page
    
- `prev`: URL to the previous page (null if on first page)
    
- `next`: URL to the next page (null if on last page)
    

### `meta` (object)

Pagination metadata:

- `current_page` (integer): The current page number
    
- `from` (integer): The starting record number on this page
    
- `to` (integer): The ending record number on this page
    
- `total` (integer): Total number of open tickets across all pages
    
- `per_page` (integer): Number of records per page
    
- `last_page` (integer): The last available page number
    
- `path` (string): Base URL path for the endpoint
    
- `links` (array): Detailed pagination links with labels and active states
    

## Example Use Cases

1. **Retrieve first page of open tickets**: Use default parameters or explicitly set `page=1`
    
2. **Navigate through pages**: Use the `next` link from the response or increment the `page` parameter
    
3. **Adjust page size**: Modify `per_page` to retrieve more or fewer tickets per request (useful for performance optimization)
    
4. **Check total open tickets**: Use the `meta.total` field to determine the total count of open tickets
    

## Response Status Codes

- `200 OK`: Successfully retrieved open tickets
    
- `401 Unauthorised`: Invalid apiToken
    
- `429 Too Many Requests`: Hit the Rate Limiting, wait 60 secs and try again.

request.description:
# Get Closed Tickets

## Overview

This endpoint retrieves a paginated list of all tickets that have been closed in the system. Each ticket includes complete details about the ticket itself and the associated user who created it.

## Endpoint Details

- **Method:** `GET`
    
- **Path:** `/api/tickets/closed`
    
- **Full URL:** `http://{{baseUrl}}/api/tickets/closed`
    

## Authentication

This endpoint requires authentication using a Bearer token. The token is provided via the `apiToken` variable.

**Header:**

```
Authorization: Bearer {{apiToken}}

 ```

## Query Parameters

This endpoint supports standard pagination query parameters:

- `page` - The page number to retrieve (optional, defaults to 1)
    
- `per_page` - Number of items per page (optional, defaults to 50)
    

## Response Structure

### Success Response (200 OK)

The response contains three main sections:

#### 1\. Data Array

An array of closed ticket objects, each containing:

- `id` (integer) - Unique ticket identifier
    
- `subject` (string) - Ticket subject line
    
- `content` (string) - Full ticket content/description
    
- `status` (string) - Current status (will be "Closed")
    
- `status_id` (integer) - Status identifier (2 for closed tickets)
    
- `created_at` (timestamp) - When the ticket was created
    
- `updated_at` (timestamp) - When the ticket was last updated
    
- `user` (object) - User who created the ticket
    - `id` (integer) - User identifier
        
    - `name` (string) - User's full name
        
    - `email` (string) - User's email address
        

#### 2\. Links Object

Pagination navigation links:

- `first` - URL to the first page
    
- `last` - URL to the last page
    
- `prev` - URL to the previous page (null if on first page)
    
- `next` - URL to the next page (null if on last page)
    

#### 3\. Meta Object

Pagination metadata:

- `current_page` (integer) - Current page number
    
- `from` (integer) - Starting record number on current page
    
- `last_page` (integer) - Total number of pages
    
- `links` (array) - Array of page link objects with labels
    
- `path` (string) - Base path for pagination
    
- `per_page` (integer) - Number of records per page
    
- `to` (integer) - Ending record number on current page
    
- `total` (integer) - Total number of closed tickets
    

## Example Response

``` json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 10,
      "subject": "Sample ticket subject",
      "content": "Detailed ticket content...",
      "status": "Closed",
      "status_id": 2,
      "created_at": "2025-12-04T11:30:16.000000Z",
      "updated_at": "2025-12-04T13:25:20.000000Z",
      "user": {
        "id": 15,
        "name": "John Doe",
        "email": "john.doe@example.com"
      }
    }
  ],
  "links": {
    "first": "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/tickets/closed?page=1",
    "last": "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/tickets/closed?page=1",
    "prev": null,
    "next": null
  },
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "from": 1,
    "last_page": 1,
    "path": "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/tickets/closed",
    "per_page": 50,
    "to": 10,
    "total": 10
  }
}

 ```

## Use Cases

- Retrieve all closed tickets for reporting purposes
    
- Display closed ticket history to users
    
- Export closed ticket data for analysis
    
- Monitor ticket resolution metrics

response.name: Closed Tickets

request.description:
# Get User Tickets

Retrieves all tickets associated with a specific user. This endpoint returns a paginated list of tickets for user ID 1, including full ticket details and associated user information.

## Endpoint
`GET /api/users/1/tickets`

## Variables Used
- `{{baseUrl}}` - The base URL for the API
- `{{apiToken}}` - Authentication token for API access

## Response Structure

The response returns a paginated collection with the following structure:

### Ticket Object Fields
Each ticket in the `data` array contains:

- **id** (integer) - Unique identifier for the ticket
- **subject** (string) - The ticket subject/title
- **content** (string) - The full content/description of the ticket
- **status** (string) - Human-readable status (e.g., "Open", "Closed")
- **status_id** (integer) - Numeric status identifier
- **created_at** (timestamp) - When the ticket was created (ISO 8601 format)
- **updated_at** (timestamp) - When the ticket was last updated (ISO 8601 format)
- **user** (object) - Nested user object containing:
  - **id** (integer) - User's unique identifier
  - **name** (string) - User's full name
  - **email** (string) - User's email address

### Pagination Structure

#### Links Object
- **first** - URL to the first page
- **last** - URL to the last page
- **prev** - URL to the previous page (null if on first page)
- **next** - URL to the next page (null if on last page)

#### Meta Object
- **current_page** (integer) - Current page number
- **from** (integer) - Starting record number on current page
- **last_page** (integer) - Total number of pages
- **links** (array) - Array of page link objects with url, label, page, and active status
- **path** (string) - Base path for pagination
- **per_page** (integer) - Number of records per page (default: 50)
- **to** (integer) - Ending record number on current page
- **total** (integer) - Total number of records across all pages

## Example Response

```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 114,
      "subject": "Ticket subject here",
      "content": "Ticket content description",
      "status": "Open",
      "status_id": 1,
      "created_at": "2025-12-04T13:25:12.000000Z",
      "updated_at": "2025-12-04T13:25:12.000000Z",
      "user": {
        "id": 1,
        "name": "Dr. Leon Jakubowski Sr.",
        "email": "alycia.herman@example.net"
      }
    }
  ],
  "links": {
    "first": "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/users/1/tickets?page=1",
    "last": "http://127.0.0.1:8000/api/users/1/tickets?page=1",
    "prev": null,
    "next": null
  },
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "from": 1,
    "last_page": 1,
    "per_page": 50,
    "to": 12,
    "total": 12
  }
}
```

## Status Code
- **200 OK** - Successfully retrieved user tickets

request.description:
# Get Ticket Statistics

## Overview
This endpoint retrieves comprehensive statistics about tickets in the system. It provides an overview of ticket counts, processing status, top contributors, and recent activity.

## Authentication
This endpoint requires authentication using an API token. The token should be provided via the `apiToken` variable.

## Response Fields

### `total_tickets` (integer)
The total number of tickets in the system across all statuses and users.

### `total_unprocessed_tickets` (integer)
The count of tickets that have not yet been processed. This helps track the backlog of pending tickets.

### `top_user` (object)
Details about the user who has created or been assigned the most tickets in the system:
- **`id`** (integer): The unique identifier of the user
- **`name`** (string): The full name of the user
- **`email`** (string): The email address of the user
- **`tickets_count`** (integer): The number of tickets associated with this user

### `most_recent_processed_at` (string)
Timestamp indicating when the most recent ticket was processed. Format: `YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS`

## Usage Notes
- This endpoint is useful for dashboard displays and monitoring ticket system health
- The statistics provide a quick snapshot of system activity and workload
- Use this data to identify high-volume users and track processing efficiency
